title: What was the transition between hand weapons and guns like? - Quora

response.answer_text: Very gradual. In the middle ages, when firearms began to slowly become recognized as viable weapons, they were cumbersome and expensive miniature versions of cannons. They needed dry wadding and powder, shot, or ball, and a viable ignition source. They were heavy, cumbersome, slow to reload, and a hard rainfall could put an entire armed force out of business, if they couldn’t keep their powder dry. Needless to say, soldiers used to hardier, lighter, quieter. and more dependable and re-usable swords, spears and long-bows were somewhat unwilling to wholeheartedly embrace being vulnerable for the 15 to 20 seconds it took to reload a firearm, if you were good at it, which most of them weren’t.. So, it was a slow change, which took over a century to take on.

Because firearms were not (and are still not particularly) cheap, the transition was slow. The first firearms made their appearance around 1400, but combat by sword was still common in the War between the States (1861) and to a lesser extent in 1918. Over time, the changes in warfare included: The disappearance of the “knight in shining armor.” By 1550, no human body could carry armor that would stop a bullet.The replacement of knights and chivalry by huddled masses of conscripts, although some chivalric ideals remained until recent times.As muskets and cannons developed, battles joining at longer ranges.

You mean “melee “weapons, not hand weapons. Firearms ,such as muskets and handguns are hand weapons. The transition was slow. Early firearms were not very effective, and hard to load and fire. And not very accurate. As firearms improved , they started to take over more and more of the melee weapons. Basically, you could train someone to use a firearm in an afternoon. Melee weapons took time and practice to learn to be used effectively.

The first word that came to my mind was “bulky”. Firearms in their earliest iterations were essentially hand cannons - big, heavy, and awkward. Metallurgy was iffy, at best. Bronze barrels and heavy stocks did not make for rapier lightness. Only the richest could afford them, much less to equip an army. The earliest ideas of fielding firearms were “we can outrange arrows”, so lets have a few fusiliers”. The evolution after that was a marvel of human ingenuity!! But slow, expensive, and heavy would describe the earliest transitions.

Not hard at all because you apply many of the same shooting techniques that you use for a rifle to handgun shooting. Things like soft trigger pull remains the same with a handgun like it does with a sniper rifle. Breathing techniques remain the same as well. The only differences involves stances and gripping the 2 different kinds of firearms.
very slowly because a lot of early firearms were inaccurate and unreliable not to mention bulky and awkward. You could depend upon your standard knife, sword, mace, club or whatever to do it’s job.
